Award.AwardTitle: Engineered Selective Pressure: Challenges and Opportunities

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid advances in the forward engineering of complex genetic circuits in living cells proved that the young discipline of Synthetic Biology has the potential to transform modern biotechnology. A predictive understanding of living systems is a prerequisite for designed manipulation in bioengineering and informed intervention in medicine. Such an understanding requires quantitative measurements, mathematical analysis, and theoretical abstraction. The advent of powerful measurement technologies and computing capacity has positioned biology to drive the next scientific revolution. Synthetic Biology provides a natural platform for the development and testing of models and general network principles using quantitative data from engineered genetic circuits. One of the major fundamental problems of Synthetic Biology is the propensity of synthetic circuits to evolve and obliterate their intended functionality. Thus, it is important to develop a quantitative approach to make genetic networks more robust and stable which also will make them more useful in therapeutic applications. The overall goal of this project to explore the challenges and exploit the opportunities that accompany the inevitable selective pressure that arises in synthetic biology through a combination of cutting-edge experimental and computational tools. Successful accomplishment of this project will lead to significant advances in understanding the interaction between synthetic circuits and host genome in the evolutionary context. This project will provide ample opportunities for cross-disciplinary training of the new generation of quantitative biologists. Furthermore, to broaden the impact of this project beyond academia, its participants will expand a highly successful elementary school science program that that foster collaboration between researchers and teachers at partner elementary schools to improve hands-on science education.

To reach the overall goal of the project, the recently developed "synchronized lysis circuit" will be used as the major focus. This synthetic gene circuit functions by triggering death of around 90% of the bacteria at a threshold population density, leaving the remaining 10% of the cells to grow back to threshold and restart the cycle. This generates a distinct phenotype characterized by population cycling that can be monitored across a wide range of length scales using micro- and bench-top chemostats. It also introduces a strong selective pressure that can lead to rapid evolution. The investigators will develop quantitative measurement technology and computational modeling that will lead to a quantitative statistical characterization of the circuit-host evolution process. Sequencing of the circuit and mutated sections of the host genome along the time course of the experiments will be used to reconstruct the evolutionary path the systems have taken. Mathematical modeling will guide experiments and help extract key parameters characterizing evolutionary dynamics of the synchronized lysis circuit. Using the gained knowledge, the researchers will engineer a "lysis circuit stabilizer" module that kills mutant bacteria losing lysis efficiency, and explore ways to use lysis circuit as a tool in directed evolution of synthetic circuits.

This award was co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology (SSB) program in the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB) Division in the Biological Sciences Directorate and the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering (BBE) program of the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET) in the Engineering Directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic biology provides a natural platform for the development and testing of models and general biological principles using quantitative data from engineered genetic circuits.  The overall goal of this project was to explore the challenges and opportunities that accompany the inevitable selective pressure that arises in synthetic biology when a synthetic circuit is integrated within the host organism.  One of the major challenges for synthetic biology is circuit stability, as mutations that disrupt circuit function are typically beneficial for the host cell. 

    In much of our work we used our recently developed "synchronized lysis circuit" (SLC) that functions by triggering simultaneous death of around 90% of the bacteria once the colony becomes sufficiently large, leaving the remaining 10% of the cells to grow back and restart the cycle.  This generates a distinct phenotype characterized by periodic population cycles. It also introduces a strong selective pressure that can affect the evolution of the circuit-host system.  We used SLC to study circuit stability and evolutionary dynamics in controlled laboratory settings. 

    We developed several novel variants of the synchronized lysis circuit, including the inducible SLC which coupled external induction, quorum sensing, and lysis within a single unit to create a platform for inducible population-dependent bacterial cargo delivery.  We also developed a synthetic circuit that provides synchronized periodic cycling of plasmid-based DNA within bacterial populations.  

    Dynamic phenotypic screening of synthetic gene circuits is crucial for synthetic biology approaches to succeed in real-world settings as a part of long-term directed evolution pipeline.  To perform long-term evolution experiments and enable a high-throughput characterization of circuit-host evolution, we constructed a scalable continuous flow system and demonstrated rapid evolution of cells possessing the synchronized lysis circuit (without the introduction of mutagens). We developed a suite of devices for the simultaneous continuous culture and measurement of up to 144 synthetic E. coli strains, acoustically loaded from liquid culture and demonstrated its utility by studying synthetic strains for environmental biosensing.

    We studied evolutionary processes in dynamic populations theoretically and computationally. Specifically, we focused the circuit mutagenesis in the case of repeated periods of exponential growth alternating with strong reductions in population size ('bottlenecks') as it occurs in the widely-used serial passage protocol but also in the dynamics of bacterial populations carrying the synchronized lysis circuit. We compared the fixation probabilities of beneficial mutations in a constant population to those in populations that undergo periodic cycles of exponential growth and pruning and confirmed that oscillatory population dynamics increases the stability of the synthetic circuit (increases the mutation fixation time). We derived analytical expressions showing that the impact of oscillatory population dynamics strongly depends on selective advantage and population size.

    We also used theoretical analysis and computational tools to investigate the role of gene conversion in evolution of native and synthetic gene circuits. Gene conversion is a known process that can copy genetic information between two very similar sections of DNA and thus propagate or eliminate mutations. We demonstrated that gene conversion can significantly speed up the multi-step evolution on rugged fitness landscapes, when a population needs to cross low-fitness “valleys” to reach higher fitness “peaks”.  We found computationally how the rate of evolution on a rugged fitness landscape changes when gene conversion mechanism is enabled. 

Our results and technology can be applied to a variety of dynamic conditions for long-term study of circuit-host co-evolution, not only in bacteria, but in yeast and other single-cell organisms. This work will be of interest to cell and molecular biologists interested in genetic networks and cell-cell communication, physicists and mathematicians interested in complex dynamical systems, collective phenomena, and the theory of evolution.
